items.title: Russian services sector sees fastest growth since January, PMI shows
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- December services PMI at 52.3, fastest growth since January, driven by stronger demand and a rise in new business (strongest since May).
- Firms cut staffing for the first time in six months amid softer business confidence; backlogs rose, signaling capacity pressures; costs rose slowly overall.
- Confidence weakened; prices charged rose more slowly; the composite PMI stayed at 50.0 as manufacturing contracted, offsetting service growth.

items.title: US approves Samsung, SK Hynix chipmaking tool shipments to China for 2026, sources say
items.author: Hyunjoo Jin
items.summary:
- The U.S. Commerce Department granted Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix an annual 2026 license to import chipmaking equipment into China, creating a year-by-year export-approval system and ending the 'validated end user' exemptions on December 31. 
- After December 31, shipments will require individual U.S. export licenses; TSMC was among firms that benefited from exemptions. 
- The move reflects a continuing U.S. effort to curb China’s access to advanced American technology while Samsung and SK Hynix depend on China as a key production base for memory chips.

items.title: Meta to buy Chinese startup Manus to boost advanced AI
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: - Meta to acquire Manus, a Singapore-based AI startup valued at about $2–$3 billion, with terms undisclosed. - Manus touts a general AI agent capable of autonomous decision-making with less prompting and claims competitive performance vs OpenAI's DeepResearch; backed by Beijing Butterfly Effect Technology; partners with Alibaba. - The deal signals Meta's aggressive AI strategy amid competition and Sino-U.S. tensions as Chinese firms re-domicile to Singapore; Manus raised $75M this year at a $500M valuation; investors include Benchmark, Sequoia China, ZhenFund and Tencent.

items.title: UK’s Octopus Energy nears Kraken stake sale, Sky News reports
items.author: Reuters
items.summary: - Octopus Energy is close to selling a 10%-20% stake in Kraken Technologies, valuing Kraken at about $9–10 billion.\n- Potential buyers include D1 Capital Partners, Fidelity, and a unit of Ontario Teachers’ Pension Plan.\n- Kraken supplies energy-software to utilities such as EDF, National Grid US, and Tokyo Gas; Sky News reported via Reuters.

items.title: Indian solar module maker Waaree Energies' CEO resigns
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- CEO Amit Paithankar resigns; insider Jignesh Rathod to succeed.
- Paithankar credited with a blockbuster IPO and expanding the U.S. market.
- Waaree is under a U.S. Customs probe over alleged tariff evasion by labeling Chinese-made cells/panels as Made in India; the company denies the claims; shares have fallen since September.

items.title: Verisk pulls plug on $2.4 billion AccuLynx deal after FTC review delay
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Verisk terminates its $2.35 billion AccuLynx deal after the FTC review extends past the December 26 deadline.
- AccuLynx says the termination is invalid; Verisk plans to defend the position and redeem about $1.5 billion of debt raised for the acquisition.
- The move could spur 2026 capital actions like share buybacks as financing is restructured.

items.title: European shares touch record high as markets resume post-holiday trading
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- European shares edged higher after the holidays, with STOXX 600 barely up and major indices mixed (DAX down ~0.2%, FTSE 100 and CAC 40 flat).
- Sectors: basic resources led gains on precious metals; tech and healthcare supported while defense/aerospace fell amid geopolitical comments; investors await Fed minutes and further rate-cut expectations.
- Notable mover: biotech Abivax rose about 3.2%.

items.title: Central bank chief urges Austria to rethink Mercosur deal opposition
items.author: Reuters

items.title: The tenuous peace between Trump and the $30 trillion US bond market
items.author: Davide Barbuscia
items.summary:
- Trump tariffs sparked a bond-market revolt; the truce is fragile as deficits and $30T of debt keep yields and term premia volatile.
- Treasury buybacks, short-dated debt, and crypto/stablecoins have cooled yields, but risk remains if inflation or Fed policy turns hawkish.
- Barbuscia presents a macro fixed-income view of the tug-of-war between deficits, investors, and policy.

items.title: South African rand softens as bullion prices take a breather
items.author: Reuters
items.summary:
- Rand weakened to 16.7025 per dollar in early trade, down about 0.3%, as investors booked profits from a bullion rally.
- Gold eased from near-record highs and silver pulled back after breaching $80/oz, as safe-haven demand cooled.
- Longer-term metals outlook remains positive in a lower-rate global environment; rand on track for gains exceeding 12% this year.
